text: UPDATED: JUN 17, 2017 Dark amber/brown color with medium brownish head. Roasted malt, toffee. Bitter taste. Nice one.

Brown, dark red color with small-medium head. In aroma roasty notes with light vanilla and grass notes. Flavor profile is also based on roasty notes with some dark fruits. Light-medium body. Dry finish. Some spicy bitterness at finish. Overall: nice one.
Dark brown color, smalle beige head. Aroma coffee, malt. Taste coffee, licorice, roasted malt, dark fruit. Dark chocolate in aftertaste.

Bottle, 0.5l. Dark ruby pour with two finger beige head, quickly diminishing, leaving good lacing. Interesting nose, fruity, forest fruits and berries. Slightly roasted. 

Thin to medium body. A bit above average carbonation, prickly on the tongue. Light texture, smooth and easy drinking. Mildly bitter taste with some fruity tart notes thrown in for a nice balance. Malty aroma, a bit of caramel, slightly roasted. Licorice. Fruity aftertaste. Forest fruits and berries. Surprisingly rich aroma. Dry mouthfeel. Lasting finish, dry and a bit peppery. Nice.

Overall, pretty good. Fairly complex, rich in aroma and very drinkable. Nice one.

From Lidl. Dark ruby body with a tan head. Malty, slightly fruity (blackberry) tart, light dry maltiness. Medium carbonation. A mix between mild roasty maltiness, breadiness and some herbal hops in the taste, vague tartness, Ends dry. Nice and complex enough. Well done!

I don't want to leave a comment. I don't want to leave a comment. I don't want to leave a comment. I don't want to leave a comment.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Tap. Clear brown with a nice light tam head. Mild aroma of dark bread and crust, toffee, toast, herbs, hints of pine, birch and mint. Nicely balanced mild roasty taste. Fairly light body, medium carbonation. Veeeery damn drinkable and sufficiently complex, well done!

Aroma: Medium-light toffee, light molasses, earthy.
Appearance: Brilliant, dark brown body with red hues. Thin, light-brown head. Low retention.
Flavour: Medium-light toffee, molasses, fruity, pear, woody, earthy, Medium-light bitterness. Medium-dry finish with lingering licorice, toffee. 
Mouthfeel: Medium body. Medium-low carbonation.
Overall: Well balanced, easy drinking, flavorful and and something to consume in liters! I wish I had more!

500 ml bottle, poured.
13A. Dark Mild
Bottle. Black with a small head. Malty medium body. Reminded me of a cross between a mild and a stout. Quite interesting and well worth trying.
Fantastic dark beer. Very warm with massive hints of chocolate. Lovely from Leeds brewery

Cask at the Leeds Brewery Tap. Pours dark brown/maroon with a lasting off white head leaving good lacing. Aroma of light toasting, chocolate, malt. Medium sweet, light roasted bitterness. Medium body, rather watery texture, soft carbonation.

Cask Pint at Wibbas Down (JDW), Wimbledon, London in May 2010 - Very Dark Reddish Brown in colour. Very Malty; lots of chocolate, roasty malts, coffee, caramel. Fruity; dark fruits and berries. Hoppy; grassy hops. Rich, sweetish, soft. Roasty chocolate and coffee malty throughout with a slight sour/bitter fruit/hop edge. Very Nice Dark Mild! (2010-05)

Bottle from Morrisons, Wakefield. Drunk at family Christmas gathering. Black beer with medium tan head. Aroma of dark malts and chocolate. Taste is chocolate, dark malts, some dark fruit and some bitterness in the finish. Good.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Cask at Brewery Tap, Leeds. Creamy white head with dark reddish brown body. Caramel aroma. Soft on the tongue. Goes down a treat.
Clear almost black pour. Some chocolate and bitterness. Good. Great Leeds Brewery beer

50cl bottle from Morrisons. 
Thin creamy off white head. Clear almost black pour. Some chocolate and bitterness. Easy drinking. Very good.

Poured from 500ml bottle. Small tasty Co2 head. Ok retention. Some lacing. Carbonic for a minute or so then pretty much goes flat. Slight coffee and vanilla aroma. Dark roast notes. some liqourish.Taste is pretty IPA style hoppy with traces of chocolate and vanilla on the palate. Watery mouthfeel. Overall a decent beer brewed in my city but nothing special and possibly best as a session drink.
Autum brown wispy head nice gentle chestnut and alcohol atoma taste caramel overipe fruit toffee very nice. Bottle from lidl rochdale
Dark mild beer with coffee and roasted chestnut aroma. Coffee and cocoa flavour, summer fruits (maybe blueberry) and liquorice. Flavour doesnt linger left a little dry on the finish

500ml bottle - Black and clear body, off white head. Roasty and toasty black malt with subtle liquorice and a touch of vanilla. Coffee, vanilla and roasted malt aroma with some plums in the mouth. Ha. Plums in the mouth.

On tap at na 7.schode. Zilina. Pours is dark with thick off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts, milk chocolate. Taste is moderate sweet with malty caramel notes, almost no bitter notes. Light body, flat carbonation, sticky texture.
Rather sweet and malty aroma and flavour, and as other beers from this pub/ brewery chain has had, a rather unpleasant finish

Tap. Pours reddish chestnut rather than black. Aroma has chocolate but something else that has kipper in it. Tastes sweet almost bubble gum. This is strongest n the finish. An interesting mild. Worth a second visit.

500ml Bottle from Lidl, Langley Moor, Durham.

Dark reddish brown with a large but loose and diminishing, frothy, tan head. Theres dark malts and cocoa in an unassuming aroma. The taste is reasonably sweet and very rich with chocolate brownie, toffee and doughy flavours on a thick, smooth palate. Its marred however by a plasticy, chemical aftertaste that means its not one Ill want to revisit.
Bottle. Pours black with a thin beige head, rich malty aroma, taste is malty and feels rich with a smooth dry finish.

[7768-20150927] Cask. Mild nutty grains aroma. Clear, dark mahogany brown body with a big thick medium-lasting foamy tan head and thick lacing. Bitter light nutty grains flavour. Medium-full body. Average. (6-/4/6/3/11) 3.0
(@ Lamb & Flag, Leeds, England)

Dark brown color with a thick beige head. Bready and some chocolate in the aroma. Medium (-) body and a soft carbonation. Tad sweet and a moderate bitterness. Oily texture. Chocolate, mild roast and bready flavor. Decent mild ale.[Handpull at The Pilgrim in Liverpool, England]

Cask at Leeds Brewery Tap. Chestnut brown. Off-white foam. Sweet malty taste. Nutty, red fruits, hint of coffee. Good flavours and a decent body. I think the higher ABV over many other milds helps this one significantly.

Fľaa. Čierna farba, bledohnedá hustá pena. Vôňa praených sladov, karamelu, kakao. V chuti jemná sladkosť, praené slady, karamel, teplé kakao. Pekná sladko horká dochuť. Veľmi osvieujúce, so stredným nasýtením.

2015-09-27. Crisp mahogany brown body with a small beige head and lace. 3+ Aroma of nutty malt, lightly earthy notes. 7+ Flavour is similar, chewy malt core has just a bit of the nutty character in the aroma, light earthy touches, sweet hints at brown sugar and treacle/caramel. 7+ Smooth average bodied palate, soft carbonation. Not really in the mood for it today but this is rather nice. Cask at The Lamb & Flag, Leeds.
Deep oak pour with a thin tan lace. Roasted malt, fruity treacle aroma and flavour. Tasty sweet brew, with a nice bitterness.
Cask at the Guildford Arms. Pours dark reddish brown, nose is chocolate, roasted, taste is similar, thin.

Drunk from 50cl bottle bought at Bier huis in Ossett. Superb dark rich and smooth ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Bier Huis, Ossett.

Pours dark brown with single finger off white head. Aroma of cherry, cream/milk/yoghurt. On the taste, Cherry then biscuit malts, then comes a dodgy yoghurty milkyness which ruined the beer for me, then back we get caramel and a light smoky finish with some dark fruits too. Would like to try again to see if I just had a dodgy bottle....or dodgy tastebuds...

Very rounded, full and sweet stout, easy to drink and lush to enjoy. Jakes favorite.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
500ml bottle, pours deep ruby red, with a lasting small off white head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt, raisin, cherry, oatmeal. medium sweetness, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, balanced finish.
Cask at The Haymarket. Pours clear dark red-brown, thick beige head. Aromas of fruit and dark chocolate. Creamy texture, light sweet taste with nice roast balance. Clean finish. Nice.

On cask at the Haymarket. 
Appearance - intriguing soft black with red chinks. 
Nose - dark chocolate with liquorice and honeycomb. 
Taste - its Crunchie Bar with liquorice. 
Palate - medium bodied with a creamy yet drying texture and a long dry but elegant finish. 
Overall - delicious. Great brew.

Cask - unfortunately a beer that suffered from the staff not being able to keep their beer properly. Deep red with a light brown. Aroma is roasty, blackcurrant, chocolate, coffee and acidy. Taste is roasty, dark fruit, some acidity and sourness.

Cask (Roebuck JDW, Nottingham) - Very dark brown with some red tinges. Raisins, caramel and a hint of marzipan in the aroma. Fruity, nutty and slightly tangy taste with notes of raisins, blackberries and some slightly buttery notes.

Gravity @ Old Horse, Leicester beer festival. Swept ruby coloured. Aroma is malty. Taste is sweetish roasted malts with slight liquorice taste, almost herbal character. Nice full body from gravity as well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask at Victoria station spooneria, 22/05/14.
Lightly hazed chestnut brown witha moderate light beige covering.
Nose is toffee, nutty pangs, vanilla Angel Delight, brown bread.
Tase comprises hazelnut, toasted brown bread, mellow dark fruit rinse, light brown sugars, hint of toffee.
Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, light drying close.
So so whelming affair.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: (draught) pours a clear ruby-amber colour with a frothy light beige head. aroma of butter, roasted malts and smoked ham, with a hint of dark chocolate and vinegar. flavour is more smoke and butter, with hints of sugar icing, grass, yeast and a dry finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.
Cask in the Swatters Carr, Middlesbrough. Mahogany with a tan head. Quite sweet at first with some red fruit and a hint of sherry. Finish is bitter and all coffee. Very nice.
UPDATED: APR 26, 2014 Lovely beer with chocolate and coffee and toffee flavours. Easy to drink and will definitely drink again.
Cask ossett beer festival. Red black colour great beige head and lacing. Slight roasted malt aroma. Taste is roasted malts slight chocolate slight bitter finish. Medium body soft carbonated. Ok.

Gravity cask @ NWAF 2014, Derby. Dark brown with a hint of ruby. Slight translucence. Woody, nutty, earthy, slightly sour aroma. Malt sweetness and hop bitterness vie for attention in the balanced taste. Bitter/sour finish, nothing much on the palette. A solid ale Id be happy to have again.

Bottle. Very dark brown, almost black, light tan head. Aromas of new carpet (weird but the first thing i got), cherries, dark fruits, toffee, roasted malt and nuts. Quite a thin mouth feel. Caramel and nuts on tasting with a spirit-esque aftertaste. 

A good beer with a decent ABV. However it would be great if the mouth feel was as full as on tap.

Cask at The Great British Beer Festival 2013. Poured a dark brown with a medium off white head. Malty aroma with chocolate and caramel notes. Nutty flavour with raisons and brown sugar. Leaves with some coffee, wood and dark fruit.
Very dark beer. Lovely chocolate and coffee aroma... Which follows in the taste. Easy to drink and full of flavour.
Cask at GBBF 2013, Olympia, London. A dark brown coloured pour with a medium white head on top. Malty, chocolate aroma. Tastes is similar, malty, chocolate, slightly roasty. Decent Mild.
mogano quasi scura leggere note tostate un tocco caffe cioccolato poco luppolata secchezza media tendeza dolce
Cask at GBBF 2013. Caramel camp coffee aroma some English yeast esters. Smooth choc roast flavour fullish body. Sweetish finish.
Dark ale with a frothy head and a nutty aroma.  Nut is also evident in its aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2012 Cask @ Old Bar, Leeds. Dark brown colour, creamy white head. Aromas of chocolate, toffee and some vegetal hop notes. Much the same in the taste. Nice dry and roasty finish. Good.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2012 Cask at Diggers
Dark brown, creamy white head with good lacing
 Aroma - dark caramel malts..slight vegetal (but not in an awful way) 
Taste - dark caramel malts...very malty...soft burnt roast...bit of coffee...some dark fruity malt in there...hint of soft coffee
Palate - soft carb...medium body...soft smooth texture...soft finish as main flavour
Overall - Really soft and easy to drink - its more a hybrid porter old ale to me
Cask by air pressure at Bow Bar, Edinburgh - clear dark red / brown ale, thin off-white head, roasted malt and chocolate aroma and flavour, good temperature, medium body, nice malty aftertaste

Cask. Dark brown, almost black with ruby highlights. Deep tan head. Malts and some hints of chocolate on the nose. Very chocolatey in mouth, some malty coffees. There's a hint of berry in this - strawberry? Nice and warming and creamy in the mouth. A slight bitterness in the palate, and dryness. Really nice.

Tasted this in the Last Post, Paisley (JDW) in March 2010. Cask, handpump dispense. Black mahogany in colour with a thick creamy buff white head - like whipped cream. Slightly sour note of pineapple and warm yeasty bread reminded me of a very weak Belhaven 90/ aroma. Silky milk like texture to the mouthfeel and poor lacing. Dark malt complex gives fruit notes of damsons, dates and plump raisins. Again a weak Belhaven 90/ comes to mind. There is no treacle or toffee notes in this but a very slight roast malt note comes through. Hint of hops evident but is rather fleeting in the aftertaste as fruit note returns in the sweet malty finish with sultanas and vinous cask notes. Starts to run out of steam before the finishing line though. Would be interesting to see what this would be like if the ABV was given the full fat factor?  Would class this as an Old Ale in style though? A good session ale and well recommended.

On cask at the Guildford Arms. Pours a very dark ruby colour with a thick, light tan head. Aroma of caramel, treacle and chocolate. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. A little dry to finish.

Hand pulled at the Shakespeare (Lower Temple), Birmingham. Very dark brown, stable cream head. Smooth caramel and marshmallow taste. Too much dishwater is sprinkled here, but otherwise a pleasant brown ale.

A - oak, roast coffee and chocolate
A - dark red with frothy head
T - sweet with roasted bitter mixed with sherry
P - mid to full and soft
O - good mild

great pint.
good dark ruby with thick white head.  
lots of roast malt, hint of liquorice, coffee, dark chocolate.  very slight vanilla note.
long dry bitter finish.  
not sure its a mild!  more stout/porter.

cask - old bell , harrogate

Id call it a porter, but apparently its considered a mild ale. I had this from a cask, somewhere in London. I forgot the name of the pub. Anyway, it has a very dark appearance that immediately grabbed my attention compared to the other cask ales in the place. The flavor is rich, bitter, roasted chocolate. Pretty tasty.
cask @ belfast beer fest 2011. dark brown. slightly watery nose but body Rich complex malt bill with sweet and dry finish.

Cask at the Grape and Grain Autumn beer festival 2011, Crystal Palace. Pours dark brown with a red tint, beige head. Treacle toffee and caramel nose. Vanilla, licorice, toffee and caramel flavours. Malt heavy finish.
Cask. The Punch Bowl (JDW), York. Tan head. Black body. Fruity, mild malt, chocolate, bubblegum, caramel. Bittersweet. Dry finish.
Half pint at Ascot Beer Festival 2011.  No head, dark brown beer.  Sweet mild, with a bit of doppelbock aroma.  A bit watery, otherwise ok.
Cask at GBBF 2011, Wednesday. Clear dark brown - offwhite head. Berries, roasted, fruity notes, tobacco, mynte - herbal, spicy, flowery, grainy, light sharpness.
Tap @ GBBF. Pours clear deep brown mahogany with a nice creamy tanned head leaving lace. Aroma is thin, malty, hoppy and phenolic. Flavor is fruity, dry, aceton tones and bitter. Finishes dry bitter.
From cask. Pours dark amber to brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is fruity and mild spiced. Sweet, bitter and slight herbal. Medium dry and slight spiced into the finish. Smooth and easy.
Cask at GBBF 2011. Black, creamy beige head. Paint aroma with some hops. Malty flavor. This was not a good beer.
Cask at GBBF 2011. Black, creamy beige head. Paint aroma with some hops. Malty flavor, some paint and solvent notes. No good.

Cask at GBBF 2011. 
Clear red brown coloured with a small beige head.
Fruity aroma of caramel, grass and hops with notes of marzipan.
Fruity flavour of caramel, grass and hops with roasted notes.
Hoppy and roasted finish.

[500ml bottle, The Bottle, York] Pours very dark red, mostly black, with only a thin lacing from the start, very little carbonation. Aroma is coffee and some chocolate but a slightly burnt malt - although not in a bad way - sensation. On the palate, dark malt which leads to a slightly thin finish before toasted dates on the palate at the end. Good mild - although strong for a traditional British mild, more a porter in my book [08032011]

Gravity cask at the Wandsworth Halloween Beer Festival, 2010. Pours ruby-brown, dark, with a moderate, off-white head. Holds a dark malt aroma with brown sugar and faint roastiness. Lightly sweet flavor with some mild fruit notes. Light to medium in body with fine carbonation. Has a sweet finish, with understated roasted malts and chocolate syrup. Quite good overall.

Cask. forgot where, maybe the Rake. Gorgeous rich red with lots of lace. Fruity aroma is enticing. Smooth with low carbonation. Fruity with nice acidity accompanied by good solid fruit, fruit sugars, and healthy British yeast. Hint of bubble gum in flavors but not enough to detract. Nice.

Dark ruby-brown.  Thin head.  Soft, toffeeish and chewy - almost date-like.  Very soft body.  The fruits are date-like and the malts are toffeeish, giving this mild a sweet and mellow but very tasty character.
Pours dark, murky brown, mouthfeel is quite thick, taste is sweet, chocolatey, malt and cocoa, nice moderated dry and slightly hoppy finish.  Good, quite tasty and flavourfull.

Cask - The Buttermarket, Canterbury. Poured with a foamy beige head atop a ruddy brown body. Sweet and creamy toffee progressing to a good roastiness on the aroma. Creamy roasted notes, a bit of dark fruit, coffee, powdery choc and a lingering finish. Soft, medium body with just a touch of carbonation. A lovely mild.
JDW Rochester. Dark amber with creamy chocolate notes that slip into greasy. Too greasy for me. Flavours ill-defined.

Cask at the Monks Retreat (JDW), Reading. Chestnut brown with a dense cream head; aroma of nutty malts; smooth and creamy texture but rather thin, with nutty malty flavours; the finish is lightly bitter and milky. An OK mild.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2014 Re-rate at the Hounslow JDW, deep dark red-brown with a lasting coarse beige head, aromas of chocolate, red fruit and grain, slighlty sour-sweet on the palate with roast malt, a touch of forest fruits and red wine, some cocoa is the mid body and finish, quite delicious.

Smooth mild with a fairly strong alc abv. Nice rich dark red blackish colour with a weak head and some lacing. Tastes quite sweet like a porter maybe. Chocolate and light berry or plum are the main notes. Finish is quite smooth and sweet with a hint of malts or smoke in the aftertaste. Quite a nice beer but not too complex.
Cask @ Paisley Beer Festival 2010. Unclear amber colour, off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts, hint of vegetables. Aroma of caramel malts, sour fruits, some roastiness.

[Gravity cask at Chippenham beerfest] Sweet with plain chocolate at first, with toffee malts and a touch of smoke coming through.  Chcolate is definitely the big theme here though, and it worked well for me.

Leeds; Cask: Dark brown body with a nice, creamy, off-white head. Fair lacings. Nose of roasted malt, caramel and chocolate/coffee notes. Sweet flavour and again with roasted malts, caramel and coffee notes. Medium bodied. Ends sweet and with a little bitterness. An OK brew.

[1/2 pint, Aire of the Dog - Leeds, 31/12/09] This is a beer that usually enjoy very much. Unfortunately, it was off at this pub and had an unpleasant sour milk taste. Will re-rate on the next occasion I drink this.
10th July 2008. Supposedly a mild but tastes more porterish. Very distinct molasses and toffee. No bitterness. Quality!

Cask Handpump at the Crown Inn, Stockport 13/06/2009
Fruit and slight roast aromas. Dark coloured strong in alcohol and fruity with a little bitterness and roast flavour in a dry lasting finish.
Cask, Peterborough Fest 09.  Dark brown with a beige foam.  Aromas are roast, earthy malts with toffee and hints of berry.  Flavours are chocolate and light roast malts with peaty notes.

Black beer with a reddish tinge.  The aroma is lightly smokey, and the flavour is lightly malty.  Overall a nice malty and lightly bitter beer.

[RBESG, Sheffield] Cask @ Riverside, Sheffield. Dark brown with a tiny but firm beige head. Roasted malty, coffee, ripe plums. Sweet malty taste with some chocolate, vanilla and a little licorice. Nice one.
Pint pulled at The Midnight Bell in Leeds, pours black. A rich malty aroma, nearly vinuous. But a light and sessionable palate, smokey with hints of coffee. Yum!
Dark brown with no head. Roasted malty aroma. Fruit, berries and roasted malt flavour

[RBESG, Sheffield]
Cask @ Riverside, Sheffield.
Pours deep chestnut with practically no head. Aroma has liqourice, soft roasted malts, blackberries and subdued dark chocolate. Prickly, low carbonation, fine mouthfeel. Flavour has liqourice, soft roasted malts, blackberries and black currants. Fine, softly roasted, dry finish.

[cask @ RBESG 2009]
Coffee, vanilla and roasted malt aroma with some plums. Garnet-black and clear. Roasty and toasty black malt with subtle liquorice and a touch of vanilla. Light body, low carbonation, nutty bitter finish.

RBESG Sheffield, day 2, Riverside. Handpull. Dark brown colour, creamy head. Aroma of slightly sour roasted malts, dark fruits. Flavour is dark fruits, chocolate, light sweet. Light bitter chocolate finish. Liked it.
Cask @ Kelham Island Tavern. Almost black. Malt and licorice in the aroma Malty sweetish flavor. Thin. Licorice and coffee.

Cask at the White Horse, 23rd April 09. Deep reddish brown with a hint of a foamy head. Lots of grape & raisin on the nose. The fruit & berry notes dominate the malt in the taste but it lacks hops to give some extra balancing dryness. Too flat also.

Cask at The Bacchus, Newcastle. A fine strong dark mild, with plenty of rich, roasted flavour. Beautiful deep black colour, with an off white head. Drinks smoothly and very more-ish. A classic example of the style.

Cask @ GBBF 2008. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty nutty aroma with some hints of caramel. Roasted malty chocolate and caramel flavor. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish.

Cask at the Vat & Fiddle. Very dark brown, this is almost a cross between a mild and a porter. The aroma is fruity and the flavour starts with a malty fruitiness with a lightly perfumed hop finish. There is a pleasing effervescence to this quaffable beer.
Cask at Guildford Arms, Edinburgh 11 Nov 08. A large creamy tanned head. Complex fruity flavor. Sweet aftertaste of caramel.

2008-12-15, Cask Conditioned at Market Porter, London, 5-4-6-3-12=30Dark brown color; thin creamy head. Some caramel and some roasted malt; smooth mouthfeel, some residual sweetness; more chocolate at the end. Average2008-12-08, Cask Conditioned at The Castle, Furnival St., London, 6-4-7-4-13=34Hazy dark brown color; thin creamy head. Light caramel aroma. Medium body, good caramel and chocolate flavor, and a yeast touch, dynamic, with quite strong bitterness. Very good, solid.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2012 Cask at cloisters edinburgh ... deep red ... light fruity licorish malt nose ... sweet juicy rich and darkberries... good hop backbone .... but a bit to hoppy for me.... man ive lost notes for this iknow i had it athe stockbridge tap... but again at cloisters ... darl red brown... sweet toffe malt nose ... soft gentle richdark fruity malt ...  rich complex and delisious

cask at guilford ... dark red brown ... thin tan head ... sweet fruity caramel toffee nose ... rch malts ... dark fruit and toffee ... hint of puff candi ... not 4.3 today more like 3.9

cask at cloisters ... deep dark brown ... thin tan head ...soft sweet roat nose ... deep malts ... thin hop nose ... nice roast ... juicy... very good 3.9
Gravity cask at the Watford beer festival..Very dark brown with a slight tan head. Sweet chocolate aroma with plenty of roasted notes. The flavour had more chocolate before a smooth, creamy finish.

Cask at Priory Arms, Stockwell, London, 21 Nov 2008. Dark brown colour, almost black, with ruby hints. Frothy, beige head. Roasted, malty nose with notes of chocolate, coffee and dark rye bread. Malty, roasted taste with chocolate, coffee, dried fruit, prunes and a slightly bittersweet finish. Medium body, fairly sweet and very tasty. Very nice mild ale. In short: coffee, chocolate and dried fruit.

Bottled, Dark brown coloured beer with some average carbonation and a large brown head. Creamy roasted yeasty fruity sweet caramel coffee perfect aroma. Smouth creamy coffee palate. Finish is weet bitter with some light roasted touches and a longer dry ending with some yeasty caramel hints. Very nice one.

Cask (handpump) @ Great British Beer Festival, GBBF 2008, Earls Court, London, England SW5.Clear dark red brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, milk chocolate, coffee. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration, good balanced. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (070808)

Half at gunpoint, Victoria Inn (Rugby) Autumn Fest 08. Buttery toffee malt aroma. Totally sweet and fudge sickliness/vanilla dominated. Hints of choc and dark fruit. Expect a bit more at 4.8%, but I suppose it is a ’premium dark mild’. Neither farts nor shits itself, as my Nan would say.

Cask at Bar Nouveau, GBBF. Deep, devil-black body with a russet tint. Sweet chocolate malts to the nose. Rounded chocolate flavour supported by roasted malts. Well bodied with a silky palate. One of the best Mild ale I have had so far. Recommendable (07.08.2008).

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Very deep amber colour, not much head. Aroma is roasted and caramel malts, mild syrup and also mild fudge and coffeeish notes. Flavour is the same along with dry dark fruits and some wooden sourness.
Dark brown with tiny off white head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and mild chocolate and coffee notes. Sweet flavor qith lots of roasted malt, caramel and chocolate notes. Ends sweet.

Cask conditioned at Merton  Summer B.F ’08. Black, red with cream head. A fruity, slightly sweet mild with an earthy, fractionally fungal notes in the background. Major flavour is of plums with a roasted malt, coffee note within. A decent enough, heavier mild, pretty decent.

Cask at Brigantes Bar, York. Lovely aroma of plum and coffee. There was a lot going on in this pint. An excellent, dark mild with loads of deep, rich flavours of sweet caramel malt with coffee and a touch of hops; it was very comforting on that frosty night in York.

Cask gravity at Bricklayers Arms 2nd Annual Yorkshire BF 08.  Ruby colour with thin beige head.  Biscuity dark fruit/blackcurrant aroma.  Some popcorn.  Some choc.  Butter popcorn flavour comes through.  Nice enough strong mild, only faint hop on finish.  Bit like a Crunchie with honeycomb taste.  Some good fruit.  Nice.
Gravity cask at the Mallard Winter Beer Festival 2008.  Pours a dark brown with no head.  Aroma is sweet malts, coffee, raisins,  chocolate.  Flavors are chocolate, caramel, and a little roastiness.
Tried it at Huddersfield beer festival a few weeks back (won all the awards there), and in other pubs around leeds since. An excellent dark mild with lovely sweet malt and soft palate. Stunning.

A Mes rate. Gravicask at Nottingham Beer Festival.Cestnut brown colour. Not much in the head department but its a really nice colour. Sweet malt, coffee and caramel, light fruit and a lovely sugary note. Tangy and a very light sourness. Interesting and just a little bit different. Enjoyed it.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 Cask, Far From The Madding Crowd, Oxford. Deep brown, just off-white head. Big handful of raisins, coffee, and milk chocolate aroma. A nice touch of perfume that my nose cant quite decide is from hops or the yeast character. Very subtle. Soft chalky roast flavor, nicely sweet and rounded. Clearly this can be a nice beer when in good nick. I thought a very pleasant pint, and Traci was particularly happy with this.
 
Previous rating, 14 Oct 2007. Gravity, Oxford CAMRA beer festival. Dark brown, rough tan head. Aroma of chocolate, raisins, rum and blackberries. Neutral coffee roast, rather sweet with some berry touches. Soft and sticky on the palate though the roast keeps it from being actually cloying. Not bad really, but could use more depth and texture. 6/3/6/3 12

Cask-conditioned at the Bag ONails, Bristol 11/10/07. Very dark brown with a slight tan head. Sweet chocolate aroma with plenty of roasted notes. The flavour had more chocolate before a smooth, creamy finish. Excellent.
I like this beer - perhaps not in preference to certain other dark beers, but still a very pleasant drink.  On draught occasionally at Arcadia (Headingley) and Dr Okells (Leeds city centre).

Cask (Peterborough BF 2007)
Sweet malty aroma. Well balanced malty and bitter combination. Like an old-style porter.

Cask at Smithfest, Smithfield pub, Derby, 08-09-07  Poured dark brown, with some nice roasted and bitter notes. Bitter roasted taste, that swiftly faded to leave some lovely sweet maltiness, flavours really swirled around in this beer which really was an excellent mild.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - Peterboro BF.  A dark brown coloured mild with an off-white head.  The aroma is smoky with a little lactic character.  The taste has roasty smoky notes together with fishiness.  Good flavours, and probably beer of the festival for me also.  Score 3.7Subsequent rating scored 3.6. Score unaltered
Cask at Peterborough BF 07. Dark red brown. Chocolate malt aroma. Sweet taste with a little bitterness. Strong but a very good mild. Top beer of the festival for me - by quite a long way.
